title: Digital Accessibility as a Business Practice
headline: Learn about digital accessibility - what it is, who it's for and how to implement it successfully - in this free course.
description: This online digital accessibility course will teach you about the value of having a web accessibility initiative in your organization. Study the digital accessibility issues for online businesses, issues faced by different people who have no digital accessibility, the digital accessibility legislation in different jurisdictions around the world, how to develop accessible applications and interfaces for user experience, and more.
courseDescription:
This course will teach you about the value of having a web accessibility initiative in your organization. Study the digital accessibility issues for online businesses, problems faced by different people who have no digital accessibility, the digital accessibility legislation in different jurisdictions around the world, and how to develop accessible applications and interfaces for a better user experience.

You will learn to appreciate the context and value of having web content accessibility guidelines (WCAG) in an organization. The course teaches you how to identify digital accessibility issues for online businesses and how to present a range of business arguments for implementing digital accessibility. You will also be introduced to the range of challenges people with digital accessibility issues face.

The material begins by exploring digital accessibility legislation in different parts of the world. You can use what you learn in this course to identify the knowledge and accessibility training requirements for various positions in an organization and you will be able to identify the required knowledge, skills and characteristics of an effective accessibility champion. You will be able to describe the use of different digital accessibility testing tools and services, and how to approach vendors in order to have accessibility standards implemented properly.

The course resources include a guide to job interview questions and answers for accessibility-aware candidates. This course is suitable as an introduction to digital accessibility and will especially appeal to those who have been delegated this responsibility in an organization. It will also be of interest to web developers and IT professionals who are increasingly expected to have knowledge and skills in this area. Start the course today and learn more about digital accessibility: what it is, who it's for and how to implement it.

Start Course Now

    • In 2011 and 2012, Karl Groves wrote an interesting series of articles (links at the end of this topic) that looked at the reality of business arguments for web accessibility. 

      He points out that any argument needs to answer affirmatively to at least one of the following questions:

      1. Will it make us money?
      2. Will it save us money?
      3. Will it reduce risk? 
      In 2011 and 2012, Karl Groves wrote an interesting series of articles (links at the end of this topic) that looked at the reality of business arguments for web accessibility. 

      He points out that any argument needs to answer affirmatively to at least one of the following questions:

      1. Will it make us money?
      2. Will it save us money?
      3. Will it reduce risk?
    • In his articles, Groves outlines a range of potential arguments for accessibility:

      • Improved search engine optimization: Customers will be able to find your site more easily because search engines can index it more effectively.

      • Improved usability: Customers will have a more satisfying experience, thus spend more or return to your site more often.

      • Reduced website costs: Developing to standard reduces bugs and interoperability issues, reducing development costs and problems integrating with other systems.

      • People with disabilities have buying power: They won’t spend if they have difficulty accessing your site; they will go to the competition that does place importance on accessibility.

      • Reduced website costs: Developing to standard reduces bugs and interoperability issues, reducing development costs and problems integrating with other systems.

      • People with disabilities have buying power: They won’t spend if they have difficulty accessing your site; they will go to the competition that does place importance on accessibility.
      In his articles, Groves outlines a range of potential arguments for accessibility:

      • Improved search engine optimization: Customers will be able to find your site more easily because search engines can index it more effectively.

      • Improved usability: Customers will have a more satisfying experience, thus spend more or return to your site more often.

      • Reduced website costs: Developing to standard reduces bugs and interoperability issues, reducing development costs and problems integrating with other systems.

      • People with disabilities have buying power: They won’t spend if they have difficulty accessing your site; they will go to the competition that does place importance on accessibility.
      Customer ID
      Customer Name
    • ARGUMENTS B.
      • Reduced resource utilization: Building to standard reduces use of resources.

      • Support for low bandwidth: If your site takes too long to load, people will go elsewhere.

      • Social responsibility: Customers will come if they see you doing good for the world, and you are thinking of people with disabilities as full citizens.

      • Support for aging populations: Aging populations also have money to spend and will come to your site over the less accessible, less usable competition.

      • Reduced legal risk: You may be sued if you prevent equal access for citizens/customers or discriminate against people with disabilities.

      Knowing the lengths your company recently went to ensure physical accessibility at the storefront locations, you are eager to gain an understanding about how accessibility legislation may extend into the digital realm. 

      The added risk of potential legal action and reference to a human rights violation in the complaint has drawn concern from the company’s leadership. They have asked you to investigate further into what legislation might already exist with reference to digital accessibility.
      Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipisicing elit, sed do eiusmod tempor incididunt ut labore et dolore magna aliqua..

    • LEGISLATION
      You discover that, in fact, there is legislation in place in Ontario as part of the Accessibility for Ontarians with Disabilities Act (AODA), specifically Section 12 and Section 14 that speak to digital accessibility, which cover accessible formats and web content, respectively. 

      You see that, indeed, accessible websites are addressed in Section 14(4).

      Knowing the lengths your company recently went to ensure physical accessibility at the storefront locations, you are eager to gain an understanding about how accessibility legislation may extend into the digital realm. 

      The added risk of potential legal action and reference to a human rights violation in the complaint has drawn concern from the company’s leadership. They have asked you to investigate further into what legislation might already exist with reference to digital accessibility.

    • LEGISLATION
      You discover that, in fact, there is legislation in place in Ontario as part of the Accessibility for Ontarians with Disabilities Act (AODA), specifically Section 12 and Section 14 that speak to digital accessibility, which cover accessible formats and web content, respectively. 

      You see that, indeed, accessible websites are addressed in Section 14(4).

  • Module One Summary

  • Main points from this module:
    • This course is aimed primarily at those who are responsible for implementing accessibility at an organizational level.
    • While managers and web developers are the primary audience for this course, anyone who has an interest in the aspects of implementing accessibility culture in an organization will find this course informative. 
    • This course’s narrative revolves around the story of “The Sharp Clothing Company”, who received a complaint about the accessibility of their online store.
    • It is up to you (course scenario) to handle the issue and to ensure that this type of complaint does not happen again. 
    • Your goal is to educate yourself about digital accessibility and implement a plan to address the complaint, to ensure no other similar complaints occur.  
    • Business arguments for web accessibility generally question: Will it make us money?; Will it save us money?; Will it reduce risk? 
    • Business arguments for accessibility include: improved search engine optimization; improved usability; a more satisfying experience; people will spend more or return to your site more often; it contributes to developing a standard that reduces bugs and interoperability issues, including integration with other systems.

  • Module Two Summary

  • Main points from this module:
    • An organization's accessibility committee will typically be comprised of people in senior positions, people with influence, and employees with disabilities.
    • Accessibility committee members must be willing to sell the ideas put forth by the committee, to raise awareness and affect the culture within the group they represent. 
    • The person in charge of the whole committee, is referred to as the accessibility champion. 
    • The accessibility champion should have expertise in the accessibility area and be able to lead, manage, change and oversee the organization’s accessibility efforts. 
    • The person who submitted the complaint against 'Sharp Clothing Co.', is blind and uses a screen reader to interpret content on the website. 
    • The complaint highlights web page images that do not have a text description (alt text) and buttons in the shopping cart area, that cannot be activated with a key press.
    • The content developer tells you the shopping cart editor does not have a way to add text descriptions to product images. 
    • The web developer explains there is no way to alter the image text or key button issues and that the vendor of the third party software is responsible.

  • Module Three Learning Outcomes

  • After completing this module you will be able to:
    • Describe the use of different digital accessibility testing tools and services
    • Explain different ways you can approach a software vendor to have accessibility standards implemented
    • Summarise the use of different techniques for spreading accessibility awareness throughout an organization
    • Justify the inclusion of certain training topics in accessibility workshops
    • Identify accessibility issues that need to be addressed in the company’s websites and outline guidelines to solve them
    • List the benefits of accessibility reviews by third-party auditors
    • Discuss accessibility barriers in addition to the Web, electronic documents and multimedia
    • Explain Kotter's eight-step change management model
    • Trace the steps in Karl Lewin's change management model

  • Introduction

  • “Culture,” in the context of digital accessibility, refers to an overarching consciousness or awareness throughout an organization, of potential barriers that may prevent people with disabilities from participating in digital activities or consuming digital information at the same level as their fully-able peers.

  • Module Three Summary

  • Main points from this module:
    • “Culture,” in the context of digital accessibility, refers to an overarching consciousness or awareness throughout an organization, of potential barriers that may prevent people with disabilities from participating in digital activities or consuming digital information, at the same level as their fully-able peers. 
    • The goal of accessibility culture, is that its attention is weaved into an organization’s processes and quality assurance, so when products and services are evaluated, accessibility is part of that evaluation. 
    • Accessibility culture means staff know how to apply accessibility into their work.
    • Digital accessibility culture requires buy-in from the most senior executive in the organization, so that it trickles down, influencing other managers and staff.
    • Accessibility concern should guide business activities: products, production, service delivery, marketing, communications, procurement and hiring.
    • One of the accessibility committee’s first tasks is to determine where the company is, in terms of its compliance with accessibility guidelines.
    • Unless there is an accessibility expert on staff, organizations likely want to hire a third-party auditor.
    • Most accessibility regulations are based on the WCAG guidelines (https://www.w3.org/WAI/standards-guidelines/wcag/).

    • The goal of accessibility culture, is that its attention is weaved into an organization’s processes and quality assurance, so when products and services are evaluated, accessibility is part of that evaluation. 
    • Accessibility culture means staff know how to apply accessibility into their work.
    • Digital accessibility culture requires buy-in from the most senior executive in the organization, so that it trickles down, influencing other managers and staff.
    • Accessibility concern should guide business activities: products, production, service delivery, marketing, communications, procurement and hiring.
    • One of the accessibility committee’s first tasks is to determine where the company is, in terms of its compliance with accessibility guidelines.
    • Unless there is an accessibility expert on staff, organizations likely want to hire a third-party auditor.
    • Most accessibility regulations are based on the WCAG guidelines (https://www.w3.org/WAI/standards-guidelines/wcag/).

    • Digital accessibility culture requires buy-in from the most senior executive in the organization, so that it trickles down, influencing other managers and staff.
    • Accessibility concern should guide business activities: products, production, service delivery, marketing, communications, procurement and hiring.
    • One of the accessibility committee’s first tasks is to determine where the company is, in terms of its compliance with accessibility guidelines.

  • Module Four Learning Outcomes

  • After completing this module you will be able to:
    • Describe how accessibility procurement practices fit into the digital accessibility policy
    • Discuss procurement as part of the organization's accessibility policy
    • Formulate accessibility statements and known-issue statements 
    • Present accessibility requirements in Requests for Proposals (RFPs)
    • Structure questions concerning accessibility to vendors during product demonstrations
    • Evaluate third party digital accessibility auditors and formulate vendor contracts
    • Present a range of arguments and discussions with vendors involving improving the accessibility of their products

  • Website Checking

  • It is often easy to get a sense of a vendor’s knowledge and commitment to accessibility, by simply looking through their website. Below are some tips on what to look out for:
    • New Tab
    • SAMPLE
    • STATEMENT
    • CONSIDER
    • REQUIREMENTS
    • REVIEW
    • Enter your text here..
      Enter your text here..
    • Sample a few pages and run them through an automated accessibility checker and HTML validator. How well do they do? The results will be a good indication of the quality and accessibility of work the company does. 
      Sample a few pages and run them through an automated accessibility checker and HTML validator. How well do they do? The results will be a good indication of the quality and accessibility of work the company does.
    • Does the vendor’s website have a prominent accessibility statement? Though not a requirement, if they do have one, it’s a good indication the company cares about accessibility.
      Does the vendor’s website have a prominent accessibility statement? Though not a requirement, if they do have one, it’s a good indication the company cares about accessibility.
    • Does the statement (if there is one), have a compliance claim and are accessibility features on the site listed? If the accessibility features are listed, it likely means they are thinking about people with disabilities who are visiting their site, which is one step above thinking about accessibility in general.
      Does the statement (if there is one), have a compliance claim and are accessibility features on the site listed? If the accessibility features are listed, it likely means they are thinking about people with disabilities who are visiting their site, which is one step above thinking about accessibility in general.
    • If there is a demo of the software you intend to procure, sample a few screens for checker and validator testing. How well do they do? You may be able to decide in this manner whether the software you are intending to procure from this company has the potential or not to meet the accessibility requirements of your organization.
      If there is a demo of the software you intend to procure, sample a few screens for checker and validator testing. How well do they do?   • Module Four Summary

  • Main points from this module:
    • This module provided you with guidance on how to create a context for accessible procurement practices, through a broader accessibility policy. 
    • It also provided information on how to document your company’s accessibility requirements, when communicating with external vendors.
    • Accessibility policies can range from simple statements outlining an organization’s commitment to web accessibility, to complex documents that describe in great detail each aspect of an organization’s digital accessibility requirements. 
    • Some accessibility policies focus specifically on the Web, ensuring web content is accessible to everyone. Others are more general, covering a wide range of accessibility matters including customer service standards, as well as accessibility of the built environment.
    • WebAIM, at the Center for Persons with Disabilities at Utah State University, undertook a project to develop an Eight-Step Implementation Model for creating an organization’s web accessibility policy.
    • WebAIM's Eight-Step Implementation Model involves: auditing of the organization’s website(s) current accessibility status; gaining buy-in from the top levels of the organization; organizing a Web 
    • Accessibility Committee; defining a standard based on WCAG 2.0; creating an implementation plan; setting timelines and priorities; delegating responsibilities; monitoring progress; providing training and technical support.

  • After completing this module you will be able to:

  • Introduction

  • This final module will expand on the discussion of policy introduced in module four. 

    One of the key elements in implementing web accessibility policy, is hiring staff that possess accessibility knowledge and ensuring they know how accessibility fits into their roles.

  • Module Five Summary

  • Main points from this module:
    • One of the key elements in implementing web accessibility policy, is hiring staff that possess accessibility knowledge and ensuring they know how accessibility fits into their roles. 
    • The Web Developer and the Web/IT Accessibility Specialist, are the two roles generally responsible for the bulk of accessibility compliance efforts undertaken in an organization. 
    • For most positions an organization may be hiring for, digital accessibility knowledge or skills need not be a requirement, though having that knowledge or skills should add points to a candidate’s overall score. 
    • For most positions, a little training will provide the necessary accessibility requirements for particular roles. 
    • Senior managers should be aware of legislated obligations concerning accessibility.
    • Office staff should be trained in document accessibility and perhaps web accessibility. 
    • Human resource staff should have knowledge of training requirements, change management and accommodations for people with disabilities.
    • Communications and marketing staff should have knowledge and skills relating to document accessibility, multimedia accessibility and basic web accessibility. 
    • Given approximately 15% of the population has a disability, a company may be missing an opportunity to benefit from diversifying its workforce, by leveraging this relatively untapped talent pool.
